notes: Descriptive paper examining trends in economics undergraduate majors by demographics (sex, race) using IPEDS aggregate data (2000-2015). Regressions are bivariate time-series OLS of economics major share on other discipline shares + year. No causal identification. Very small N (collapsed to ~16 year-level observations). The regression content is limited: Table 1 regressions of econshare on each discipline's share individually, with robust SEs. Purely descriptive/correlational.

design_audit.notes: Bivariate OLS: econshare ~ level_d{j} + year, robust SEs. Each regression uses one other discipline's share as the sole covariate (plus year). Data collapsed to year level (~16 obs). Repeated for 11 disciplines (d2-d12), separately for all students, females, and nonwhites.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Share of economics BA majors among all BA majors
claim_object.treatment_concept: Share of another discipline (e.g., business, poli sci, psych, etc.) among all BA majors
claim_object.estimand_concept: Descriptive partial correlation between economics share and other discipline share, conditional on year trend
claim_object.target_population: All US undergraduate degree completions (IPEDS data, 2000-2015)

baseline_specs.label: Table1-AllStudents-BusMgmt
baseline_specs.notes: regress econshare level_d2 year, robust. Business/management share is the most commonly reported comparison discipline.

constraints.notes: All regressions include exactly one discipline share + year. The paper never uses multiple discipline shares simultaneously. Year is always included.

canonical.notes: Heteroskedasticity-robust SEs, matching the paper's 'robust' option.

variants.notes: Newey-West HAC SEs (time series, potential serial correlation with ~16 obs).

budgets.notes: The specification space is naturally small: 11 discipline shares x ~5 sample/form variants. No controls multiverse since each regression uses exactly one discipline share. Budget reflects the many baseline variants (one per discipline) plus sample/form RC.

sampling.notes: Full enumeration feasible. No control subset sampling needed.
